vWashington House Rabbit Newsv

Volume 6 Issue 4 December 1997

REDMOND RABBIT RESCUE

The Consequences of Years of Rabbit Dumping

By Jill Tamane

In the midst of recent publicity surrounding the Redmond feral rabbit controversy, lies a significant issue that went virtually ignored by the media. It is a concern that the House Rabbit Society has voiced loudly since its inception: place unwanted pet bunnies into another home, refrain from dumping rabbits into "natural settings."

For the last few decades what is currently a business park in the city of Redmond, has continued to be a well-known area for dumping pet bunnies. Property owners originally encouraged dumping on the site as they considered the abundance of rabbits to be an attraction. HRS saw it differently and offered to neuter/spay the rabbits then re-release them onto the site. The park's businesses turned down all offers by HRS.

Against nature's odds and in spite of continued development in the business park, the colony's population grew (fueled by regular feeding by employees and visitors). Rabbits were forced to seek other living areas as the site decreased in size due to continued construction. The rabbits were crowded onto the highways that bordered a segment of the park. During a recent land clearing on the site, a local traffic report announced a caution to drivers as a large number of rabbits were running around the busy highway in the area. Dead rabbits are an increasingly common sight on the roadside near the Redmond business park.

In April of this year, a tenant of the property contacted HRS citing that the rabbits had eaten thousands of dollars worth of landscaping, and they wanted to rid the property of rabbits. By October 19, 1997, "Hare Transplant Operation" was underway with the enormous task of rescuing the rabbits and eventually relocating or adopting them to good homes. HRS,  Rabbit Haven, and caring veterinarians (all donating their time) rescued 49 rabbits during the initial roundup (763 was the final count).

Upon reporting about the rescue operation, a local newspaper stated that "hundreds of rabbits . . . were killed recently as a result of . . . work at a construction site. . . ." The article barely mentioned the deaths of thousands of rabbits that began decades before the recent construction work because of owners dumping their unspayed and unneutered rabbits.

Releasing a pet bunny into a "natural setting" is equivalent to giving it a death sentence. Thousands of death sentences were carried out over the last 20 or 30 years.

Dumped pet bunnies cannot live as feral rabbits do. Feral rabbits have lived without human contact for many generations. They are acclimated to the outdoors and attuned to the sights, smells, and sounds of the environment. Feral rabbit colonies do not accept domestic rabbit newcomers into their social group very easily. A rescued bunny from the Redmond site was dumped very recently. The sweet Netherland Dwarf shows evidence of a battle resulting in one blind eye. Parasites, such as a lethal liver coccidia and other diseases are often widespread among the feral colony members. The result is a colony with very few members older than one year old.

Domestic rabbits are acclimated to living in a home. They rely on their owners for food and affection. They are accustomed to human interaction and lack the ability to recognize the dangers of the outdoors. In the winter months when food sources are scarce, domestic bunnies are easily spotted by hungry predators on the site. Business park employees have reported hawks and coyotes carrying off rabbits on a daily basis. The "natural setting" is foreign to a domestic bunny, as they are known to stay in the same area they were originally dropped off and rarely wander far from it.

Presently, the Redmond feral rabbit colony contains well over 500 rabbits that remain on the business park grounds.

The task of rescuing what has resulted over the last three decades is a major one. It will require hundreds of volunteers and veterinarians to rescue, spay/neuter, medicate, and relocate the rabbits. It is anticipated that the rescue project may take up to one year.

Money is extremely limited. Bills for supplies and veterinary expenses have yet to be paid. Costs are estimated at $60 per rabbit for spay/neuter operations, food, medication, and other veterinary expenses. HRS is depending upon fund raising and donations to cover most of the costs.

The House Rabbit Society discourages anyone from attempting to rescue these rabbits on their own. "Well-meaning individuals are `rescuing' rabbits at night, not knowing that they are taking the deadly coccidia to any other rabbits they have at home," says Sandi Ackerman, Washington HRS Chapter Manager.

Sending negative messages to the companies involved are discouraged by HRS as the project has turned precarious following the negative publicity presented by the media. "Every threatening phone call and email message they receive causes more hostility," explained Sandi. "Project negotiations are currently ongoing with the companies and these negative contacts are detrimental. "

HRS picked up 49 rabbits from the site on October 19 and currently most are healthy enough to be removed from quarantine. We anticipate picking up approximately 50 rabbits every day that we trap. As of November 12, 63% of the rabbits tested positive for liver coccidia. Following three and a half weeks of medication, all but one have tested negative for all parasites. Thirteen rabbits were successfully spayed, 12 rabbits were successfully neutered, and one rabbit was euthanized due to excessive internal abscesses and cancer. One rabbit gave birth to five babies on October 20, and is doing well with three of the five babies available for adoption at the end of December (two have already been claimed for adoption). Upon closer examinations some interesting cases were found, including: a mummified baby attached to the uterus of rabbit; an old knee injury that resulted in osteoarthritis in the same rabbit; another had a mass in his right testicle and a scarred left testicle. Once all the rabbits are healthy, each will be placed into foster homes or adopted; and the next round of Hare Transplant Operation would begin pending negotiations with the park's businesses.

Will the rabbits make good house buns? Yes. Feral rabbits are not wild. Most of the rescued rabbits are dependent on being fed by people as they were in the business park. Many are unafraid of people and have very friendly dispositions. They will make excellent house buns with the help of foster care.

HRS is desperate for volunteers and veterinarians to help care for the rescued rabbits. Money is needed to continue this operation. Foster homes are needed to help the rabbits adjust to their new homes. The 30-day commitment by volunteers of the two major companies ended on November 18. Fosterers and adopters are needed immediately.

Fostering a rabbit entails taking one or two rabbit(s) into your home for about two to four weeks. We ask that you spend time with the rabbit on a one-to-one basis to get them used to the sounds and movements of our homes, and to let them know that being constantly petted, snuggled, kissed, and loved is a good thing. HRS will hold two foster care classes for those who wish to learn more about fostering.

If you would like to help, please contact HRS, phone (425) 868-4839, and let us know! We need your help. We cannot do this alone.
